sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The succ function accepts an integer, character or an enumerated value and returns the integer plus one, the next character, or the next value in the enumeration. For example, succ (7) is 8.
sections.text_content: The succ function accepts an integer, character or an enumerated value and returns the integer plus one, the next character, or the next value in the enumeration. For example, succ (7) is 8.
sections.mdown_content: The **succ** function accepts an integer, character or an enumerated value and returns the integer plus one, the next character, or the next value in the enumeration. For example, **succ** (7) is 8.

sections.title: Example
code:
type colors : enum ( green, yellow, red  )
        var a : array 1 .. 100 of colors
        var c : colors := colors .green
        for i : 1 .. 100
            a ( i ) := c
            if c = colors . red then
                c := colors . green
            else
                c := succ ( c )
            end if
        end for
sections.raw_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array a with the enumerated values green, yellow, red, green, yellow, red, etc.
sections.text_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array a with the enumerated values green, yellow, red, green, yellow, red, etc.
sections.mdown_content: This part of a Turing program fills up array _a_ with the enumerated values _green_, _yellow_, _red_, _green_, _yellow_, _red_, etc.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content: You cannot apply succ to the last value of an enumeration.
sections.text_content: You cannot  apply succ to the last value of an enumeration.
sections.mdown_content: You cannot  apply **succ** to the last value of an enumeration.

sections.title: See also
sections.raw_content: the pred, lower and upper functions.
sections.text_content: the pred, lower and upper functions.
